A data structure is a way of organizing and storing data so that it can be accessed and modified efficiently.

user_input: what are the types of data structures
bot_response: There are four main types: Linear (Array, Linked List), Non-Linear (Tree, Graph), Hashing, and Special (Heap, Stack, Queue).
An array is a collection of elements stored at contiguous memory locations.
A linked list is a linear data structure in which elements are stored in nodes, each containing a reference to the next node.
A stack is a LIFO (Last In, First Out) data structure used for operations like backtracking, undo, and function calls.
A queue is a FIFO (First In, First Out) data structure used in scheduling, buffering, and networking applications.
A hash table is a data structure that stores key-value pairs using a hash function for fast lookups.
A binary tree is a tree data structure where each node has at most two children: left and right.

user_input: what is a binary search tree
bot_response: A BST is a binary tree where the left subtree contains only nodes with values less than the root, and the right contains only nodes with greater values.
A graph is a non-linear data structure consisting of vertices (nodes) and edges (connections between nodes).
Dynamic Programming is an optimization technique used to solve problems by breaking them into smaller subproblems and storing results to avoid redundant calculations.
Recursion is a technique where a function calls itself to solve a problem with smaller subproblems.
A Trie is a tree-like data structure used for storing dynamic sets of strings efficiently, often used in autocomplete and search engines.
A heap is a specialized tree-based data structure that satisfies the heap property, used in priority queues and heapsort algorithms.
A priority queue is a queue where each element has a priority, and elements with higher priority are dequeued before lower-priority elements.
Time complexity is a measure of the computational complexity of an algorithm, describing how the execution time grows with input size.
Space complexity measures the total memory required by an algorithm as a function of input size.
Big O notation is used to describe the upper bound of an algorithm's time or space complexity.
An adjacency matrix is a 2D array representation of a graph where rows and columns indicate the presence of edges.
An adjacency list represents a graph using lists of connected nodes, making it more space-efficient for sparse graphs.
A spanning tree is a subgraph of a graph that connects all vertices with the minimum number of edges.
Dijkstra's algorithm is used to find the shortest path from a source node to all other nodes in a weighted graph.
The Floyd-Warshall algorithm is used for finding the shortest paths between all pairs of nodes in a weighted graph.
The Bellman-Ford algorithm finds the shortest paths from a single source vertex to all other vertices, even with negative weight edges.
The knapsack problem is a combinatorial optimization problem where we maximize value while staying within a weight limit.
The Traveling Salesman Problem is an optimization problem that seeks the shortest possible route visiting each city exactly once and returning to the start.
Backtracking is an algorithmic technique used for solving problems by exploring all possible solutions and abandoning infeasible ones.
DFS is a graph traversal technique that explores as far as possible along a branch before backtracking.
BFS is a graph traversal technique that explores all neighbors of a node before moving deeper into the graph.
Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) is a programming paradigm based on the concept of objects, which contain data and behavior.

user_input: what are the four pillars of OOP
bot_response: The four pillars of OOP are Encapsulation, Abstraction, Inheritance, and Polymorphism.
Encapsulation is the bundling of data and methods that operate on that data into a single unit (class) to restrict direct access.
Abstraction is the process of hiding implementation details and exposing only the necessary functionalities to the user.
Inheritance is a mechanism where one class (child) derives the properties and behavior of another class (parent).
Polymorphism allows one interface to be used for multiple functionalities, such as method overloading and method overriding.
Method Overloading allows multiple methods in the same class to have the same name but different parameters.
Method Overriding allows a subclass to provide a specific implementation of a method that is already defined in its superclass.
A constructor is a special method in a class that initializes an object when it is created.
A destructor is a special method that is automatically invoked when an object is destroyed to free resources.
A class is a blueprint for creating objects, while an object is an instance of a class.

user_input: what is the difference between class and object
bot_response: A class is a template, whereas an object is an instance of that template containing real values.
Multiple Inheritance is when a class inherits from more than one base class.
Hybrid Inheritance is a combination of multiple types of inheritance (e.g., multiple and hierarchical inheritance).
An interface is an abstract type that defines a contract for classes to implement but does not provide implementation details.
An abstract class is a class that cannot be instantiated and may contain abstract methods that must be implemented by derived classes.

user_input: what is the difference between an abstract class and an interface
bot_response: An abstract class can have both abstract and non-abstract methods, while an interface only has abstract methods (before Java 8).

user_input: what is solid principle in oop
bot_response: SOLID is an acronym for five design principles: Single Responsibility, Open-Closed, Liskov Substitution, Interface Segregation, and Dependency Inversion.

user_input: what is the difference between static and dynamic binding
bot_response: Static binding occurs at compile-time (method overloading), while dynamic binding occurs at runtime (method overriding).

user_input: what is the difference between composition and inheritance
bot_response: Inheritance is a 'is-a' relationship where a class extends another, while composition is a 'has-a' relationship where a class contains another class.
An API (Application Programming Interface) allows different software systems to communicate with each other.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a field of computer science that enables machines to perform tasks that typically require human intelligence.

5G is the fifth generation of mobile networks, offering faster speeds and lower latency than 4G.
The Internet of Things (IoT) refers to a network of interconnected devices that communicate and share data.

The internet was developed by multiple researchers, but ARPANET, created by the U.S. Department of Defense, was its foundation.
Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants use sunlight to convert carbon dioxide and water into oxygen and glucose.
